The Conversion Formulas

Fahrenheit to Celsius: (Â°F - 32) Ã— 5/9 = Â°C. So 72Â°F: (72-32) Ã— 5/9 = 40 Ã— 0.556 = 22.2Â°C.

Celsius to Fahrenheit: (Â°C Ã— 9/5) + 32 = Â°F. So 25Â°C: (25 Ã— 1.8) + 32 = 45 + 32 = 77Â°F.

Those formulas are precise but hard to do in your head. Use these shortcuts instead.

The Quick Estimation Trick

Celsius to Fahrenheit: Double it and add 30. This gives you a surprisingly close estimate for everyday temperatures. 10Â°C â†’ 50Â°F (exact: 50Â°F, perfect). 20Â°C â†’ 70Â°F (exact: 68Â°F). 30Â°C â†’ 90Â°F (exact: 86Â°F). 35Â°C â†’ 100Â°F (exact: 95Â°F).

Fahrenheit to Celsius: Subtract 30, then halve it. 70Â°F â†’ 20Â°C (exact: 21.1Â°C). 90Â°F â†’ 30Â°C (exact: 32.2Â°C). It gets less accurate at extremes, but for weather temperatures it works great.

Weather Reference Points

Hereâ€™s what common Celsius temperatures feel like in Fahrenheit terms:

-10Â°C (14Â°F) is bitterly cold â€” heavy winter coat, gloves, hat mandatory. 0Â°C (32Â°F) is freezing â€” literally, water turns to ice. 10Â°C (50Â°F) is cool â€” light jacket weather. 20Â°C (68Â°F) is comfortable room temperature. 25Â°C (77Â°F) is warm and pleasant. 30Â°C (86Â°F) is hot â€” summer day. 35Â°C (95Â°F) is very hot â€” stay hydrated. 40Â°C (104Â°F) is dangerously hot â€” heat advisory territory.

Cooking Temperatures

Oven temperatures are where Fahrenheit-Celsius confusion causes the most practical problems.

150Â°C = 300Â°F (low/slow cooking). 180Â°C = 350Â°F (standard baking â€” cookies, cakes). 200Â°C = 400Â°F (roasting vegetables, chicken). 220Â°C = 425Â°F (high-heat roasting, pizza). 230Â°C = 450Â°F (bread, high-heat searing).

For meat doneness: Rare beef is 125Â°F (52Â°C). Medium is 145Â°F (63Â°C). Well-done is 160Â°F (71Â°C). Chicken must reach 165Â°F (74Â°C) for food safety.

Medical Temperatures

Normal body temperature: 98.6Â°F (37Â°C). Low-grade fever: 99-100.3Â°F (37.2-37.9Â°C). Fever: 100.4Â°F+ (38Â°C+). High fever requiring medical attention: 103Â°F+ (39.4Â°C+). Hypothermia: below 95Â°F (35Â°C).

For children, always consult a pediatrician for fevers over 100.4Â°F (38Â°C) in infants under 3 months.

â“ Frequently Asked Questions

What temperature is the same in both Fahrenheit and Celsius? â–¼

-40 degrees is the same in both scales. This is the only point where Fahrenheit and Celsius intersect.

What is normal body temperature in Fahrenheit and Celsius? â–¼

Normal body temperature is 98.6Â°F (37Â°C), though individual normal ranges vary from about 97Â°F to 99Â°F (36.1Â°C to 37.2Â°C). A fever is generally considered 100.4Â°F (38Â°C) or higher.

Why does the US use Fahrenheit? â–¼

Daniel Fahrenheit's scale was widely adopted in English-speaking countries in the 1700s. When most of the world switched to Celsius in the mid-20th century, the US chose not to mandate the change, though Celsius is used in US science and medicine.

What's the fastest way to estimate Celsius to Fahrenheit? â–¼

Double the Celsius number and add 30. It's not exact but works well for everyday temperatures. Example: 20Â°C â†’ (20Ã—2)+30 = 70Â°F (actual: 68Â°F). Close enough for deciding what to wear.
